proof:
We know that $\Delta$ is distributed as $N(d - \mu, 1/n)$, which implies that with high probability, $d - \mu - \frac{1}{2}e^{-d/3} < \Delta$. For any $d \ge 3$, we have the bound $\mu \le e^{-d/2} < e^{-d/3}$, and from this it follows that $\Delta > d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$.

From a previous lemma, it is established that with high probability, $n-n_K \le ne^{-d/3}$. Additionally, we can state the inequality $2|E_K| \ge \sum^n D_i - 2(n-n_K)$. Therefore, it becomes sufficient to demonstrate that with high probability, $\sum^n D_i \ge n(d-2e^{-d/3})$. Because the probability that $\sum D_i$ is an even number is bounded from below by a constant, this is equivalent to showing that with high probability, a Poisson random variable with mean $\Delta n$ satisfies $\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \ge n(d-2e^{-d/3})$.

Since we have established that $\Delta \ge d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$ with high probability, it follows from relation (9) that the probability of the complementary event is exponentially small, i.e., $P(\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \le n(d-2e^{-d/3})) = e^{-\Omega(n)})$. The claim for the $G(n, d/n)$ model is then a consequence of the contiguity of $K(n, d)$.
